title: The Air Travel Trends That Will Shape 2026 | OAG
description:
John Grant brings together schedule data, pricing insights, and operational experience to connect the dots between today’s trends and the year(s) ahead.
Here he shares his perspective on how current trends may play out over the coming year and beyond.
Low-Cost Carriers Continue to Drive Airline Growth Through to the end of this decade, expect most growth globally to be generated from the low-cost airline sector.
Smart Airlines Will Gain an Advantage with AI Expect lots of stories around AI and its increasing use in the industry with many of the developments in operational areas.
We expect that to comfortably break the 50,000 mark in 2026 with many transatlantic services added.
text:
John Grant brings together schedule data, pricing insights, and operational experience to connect the dots between today’s trends and the year(s) ahead. Here he shares his perspective on how current trends may play out over the coming year and beyond.

Low-Cost Carriers Continue to Drive Airline Growth

Through to the end of this decade, expect most growth globally to be generated from the low-cost airline sector. Major low-cost operators are due to receive their latest aircraft orders and will expand their networks further. And for many of those airlines we should expect to see an ever-greater focus on ancillary product revenues and maybe even some premium products coming to the market.

Smart Airlines Will Gain an Advantage with AI

Expect lots of stories around AI and its increasing use in the industry with many of the developments in operational areas. Every slight efficiency gained by using AI should result in a cost benefit to the airlines and improved margins for those clever airlines that test thoroughly and adopt early.

Record Revenues For Many Airlines?

Based on current demand and capacity trends, 2026 looks set to be a good year with the potential for record levels of profitability for most airline CEOs with the potential for record levels of profitability. Even some of the less efficient national airlines could break even. Demand continues to be strong Ddespite concerns around economic growth and consumer confidence d, emand continues to be strong, and a weakening of the US Dollar would be a positive for many airlines.

Track Airfares Trends >>

Expect More Longer Narrow-Bodied Flights

In 2025, there were some 44,400 narrow-bodied flights - an increase of over 18% compared to 2024 - that lasted in excess of more than seven hours and thirty minutes, an increase of over 18% on the 2024 number. We expect that to comfortably break the 50,000 mark in 2026 with many transatlantic services added.

Airlines Will Adapt to Geo-Political Events – at a Cost

Sadly, the reach of geo-politics will never be far away and is always outside the control of the airlines that are inevitably impacted. Airlines and their management teams are very skilled at flipping capacity when necessary, but it always takes a lot of effort and cost.

Sustainability Will Improve, But Targets Remain Hard to Reach

Progress will be made on many sustainability fronts from Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) through to airport facilities and operational vehicles, but meeting the industry’s targets remains almost impossible given where we are today.

European Strikes in the Summer

title: MAG reveals how Gen Z travellers are shaping airport retail and destination trends
description:
MAG reveals how Gen Z travellers are shaping airport retail and destination trends Manchester, London Stansted and East Midlands airports are seeing Gen Z reshape travel, using AI, social media and wellness trends in terminals.
Generation Z travellers are changing the airport experience, with social media, wellness trends and artificial intelligence shaping how younger passengers plan holidays and spend in terminals, according to the UK’s largest airport group, MAG.
Sales of products favoured by Gen Z have soared across terminals.
Matcha is particularly popular, with sales climbing 165 percent across MAG airports compared with last year.
Gen Z passengers are also embracing technology, with one in four now using AI to plan their trips.
text:
MAG reveals how Gen Z travellers are shaping airport retail and destination trends

Manchester, London Stansted and East Midlands airports are seeing Gen Z reshape travel, using AI, social media and wellness trends in terminals.

Generation Z travellers are changing the airport experience, with social media, wellness trends and artificial intelligence shaping how younger passengers plan holidays and spend in terminals, according to the UK’s largest airport group, MAG.

Manchester Airport (MAN), London Stansted Airport (STN) and East Midlands Airport (EMA) are seeing significant shifts in passenger behaviour, as younger travellers opt for matcha drinks over pre-flight fry-ups and invest in skincare products rather than traditional holiday items such as swimwear.

Sales of products favoured by Gen Z have soared across terminals. Giant Stanley Cups, for example, have seen a six-fold increase in sales since being introduced to JD Sports stores at all three airports. Hydrating facemasks have also surged, with some items up by 399 percent year-on-year, reflecting the “skincare in the sky” trend popularised on TikTok and other social media platforms.

Matcha is particularly popular, with sales climbing 165 percent across MAG airports compared with last year. London Stansted saw a 174 percent increase, Manchester 144 percent, with outlets including Pret a Manger, Itsu, Caffè Nero and Pasta Evangelists benefiting. Smoothie sales also soared, with Innocent Energise and Defence drinks collectively up 650 percent, becoming a popular addition to budget-conscious meal deals.

Gen Z passengers are also embracing technology, with one in four now using AI to plan their trips. East Midlands Airport leads in the proportion of under-25s using AI tools such as ChatGPT to design holidays. European city breaks top the list of destinations, overtaking traditional package holidays once favoured by older generations. Dublin, Amsterdam and Barcelona are among the most popular, while more adventurous travellers are visiting destinations such as Albania, Bulgaria, Romania and Mumbai, which have seen growth of 97 percent and 245 percent respectively since 2019.

Andrew MacMillan, MAG Chief Strategy Officer, said: “As consumer trends evolve, so does the travel industry – that’s both in terms of the destinations we work with our airlines to provide and the kind of products people want to consume in terminals. This data shows the influence of our younger passengers – Generation Z – who are curating airport experiences strongly influenced by AI and social media. It is clear these travellers both want to follow trends and set them. With an ongoing £2bn investment across all three MAG airports, we will continue to focus on how the airport experience can embrace new technology and ensure that it reflects emerging demographics into the future.”

title: Advances in Aircraft Nacelle Systems Support Sustainable Aviation - ePlaneAI
description:
Aerospace Dynamics Innovations has announced significant breakthroughs in aircraft nacelle systems designed to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce environmental impact across both commercial and general aviation sectors.
These next-generation nacelle systems incorporate lightweight composite materials and advanced aerodynamic designs, establishing new benchmarks as the aviation industry intensifies its commitment to sustainability.
High development and implementation costs, slow adoption of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and complex regulatory environments continue to impede progress.
The Strategic Role of Nacelle Systems Aircraft nacelle systems play a critical role in shaping an aircraft’s aerodynamic profile, directly influencing fuel savings and emissions reductions.
As the aviation industry confronts the challenges of sustainability, innovation in nacelle systems remains central to achieving cleaner and more efficient skies.
text:
Aerospace Dynamics Innovations has announced significant breakthroughs in aircraft nacelle systems designed to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce environmental impact across both commercial and general aviation sectors. These next-generation nacelle systems incorporate lightweight composite materials and advanced aerodynamic designs, establishing new benchmarks as the aviation industry intensifies its commitment to sustainability.

Market Growth Driven by Efficiency and Modernization

The global aircraft nacelle systems market is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of approximately 5.5% through 2031, driven by increasing air passenger traffic and ongoing fleet modernization efforts. A prominent trend within the industry is the adoption of lightweight composites and hybrid materials, which can reduce nacelle weight by up to 20%, thereby directly improving fuel economy for narrowbody and widebody aircraft alike.

Recent developments highlight this momentum. In late 2025, Safran and Collins Aerospace unveiled upgraded nacelle designs for the Boeing 737 MAX, focusing on enhancing thrust reverser efficiency amid strong demand for narrowbody jets. Spirit AeroSystems introduced advanced composite nacelles for regional jets, targeting a 15% weight reduction to support the growth of low-cost carriers in the Asia-Pacific region. At the 2025 Paris Air Show, Leonardo S.p.A. showcased noise-reduction technologies aligned with the European Union’s Green Deal regulations. Meanwhile, GKN Aerospace advanced hybrid-electric nacelle prototypes in preparation for urban air mobility fleets anticipated by 2030.

Challenges and Industry Response

Despite these technological advances, the transition to sustainable aviation faces significant challenges. High development and implementation costs, slow adoption of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and complex regulatory environments continue to impede progress. The long service life of aircraft and the sluggish uptake of SAF—issues underscored by figures such as Bill Gates and the International Air Transport Association—highlight the sector’s difficulty in rapidly reducing emissions.

In response, industry leaders are accelerating research and development, forging partnerships to develop next-generation nacelles, and investing in SAF infrastructure. These initiatives have attracted growing investor interest, as stakeholders recognize the urgent need for innovation and stronger government policies to reduce aviation emissions.

The Strategic Role of Nacelle Systems

Aircraft nacelle systems play a critical role in shaping an aircraft’s aerodynamic profile, directly influencing fuel savings and emissions reductions. Engineers at Aerospace Dynamics Innovations have collaborated closely with pilots and maintenance crews to ensure these systems meet practical operational requirements. The industry is increasingly moving away from traditional metal nacelles toward carbon-fiber reinforced polymers, which offer superior strength-to-weight ratios. In modern fleets equipped with high-bypass turbofan engines, advanced nacelle systems optimize airflow to minimize drag, a crucial factor as airlines prioritize efficiency in the post-pandemic recovery period.

Recent approvals by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for acoustic metamaterials are also enabling quieter takeoffs, an important development for operations at urban airports.

Regional and Global Outlook

Commercial aviation remains the primary driver of nacelle system demand, with narrowbody aircraft such as the Airbus A320neo leading due to their high production volumes. Military applications are also growing steadily, particularly in the development of stealth nacelle designs for next-generation fighter aircraft. North America dominates the market with well-established supply chains, while Europe emphasizes sustainability initiatives. The Asia-Pacific region is the fastest-growing market, propelled by airline expansions in India and China. Emerging markets, including Brazil, contribute through retrofit programs.

Looking forward, forecasts indicate sustained market growth, with electric propulsion nacelles expected to disrupt the sector by 2028. Key industry players include Cadence Aerospace, Du Pont, GE Aviation, Gulfstream Aerospace, Kawak Aviation, Melrose Industries, Raytheon Technologies, Safran SA, and ST Engineering.

As the aviation industry confronts the challenges of sustainability, innovation in nacelle systems remains central to achieving cleaner and more efficient skies.

title: Rolls Royce Appoints Ivanka Mamic as New Chief Sustainability Officer, Head of ... - ESG News
description:
Appointment blends sustainability, policy and geopolitical engagement across a strategic industrial sector Follows bp’s internal realignment toward greater oil and gas investment and lower low carbon capex Highlights intensifying race for industrial firms to shape climate, energy and policy pathways Rolls Royce has appointed former bp Chief Sustainability Officer Ivanka Mamic as Global Head of Government Relations and Chief Sustainability Officer.
The decision to combine sustainability with government relations is notable for a firm that operates across regulated markets, sovereign-level procurement, and long-duration climate and energy transition cycles.
Mamic joins after five years at bp, where she led the design and execution of the company’s global sustainability strategy.
For institutional investors with exposure to aerospace, defense and energy transition infrastructure, the combined government relations and sustainability role may streamline engagement on climate transition, industrial policy, and regulatory risk.
The global significance of the move lies in a broader trend: climate transition is becoming inseparable from geopolitics, industrial strategy and national security.
text:
Appointment blends sustainability, policy and geopolitical engagement across a strategic industrial sector

Follows bp’s internal realignment toward greater oil and gas investment and lower low carbon capex

Highlights intensifying race for industrial firms to shape climate, energy and policy pathways

Rolls Royce has appointed former bp Chief Sustainability Officer Ivanka Mamic as Global Head of Government Relations and Chief Sustainability Officer. The new post places sustainability and government engagement within a single leadership portfolio at one of Britain’s most strategically important industrial technology companies.

A Strategic Hire at a Geopolitical Moment

Rolls Royce has been positioning its civil aerospace, defense, and emerging energy systems businesses for a decade defined by decarbonisation, industrial security, and techno-political competition. The decision to combine sustainability with government relations is notable for a firm that operates across regulated markets, sovereign-level procurement, and long-duration climate and energy transition cycles.

Mamic joins after five years at bp, where she led the design and execution of the company’s global sustainability strategy. Her tenure coincided with bp’s public push into low carbon energy and investor engagement on climate transition through 2020 to 2023, followed by a strategic rebalancing last year. That shift included a larger allocation of capital to oil and gas and reduced capex for low carbon investments to below five percent.

Before bp, Mamic spent nearly a decade in sustainability-focused roles at Target, including oversight of global responsible sourcing. She has worked across decarbonisation strategy, supply chain accountability and corporate governance, and has engaged with regulators and investors on the materiality of climate risk.

Personal Statement as Transition Marker

In a public statement announcing her move, Mamic said she was motivated by mission focus and industrial heritage. She noted: “As someone with a strong interest in enduring, mission-driven companies, I am proud to join this iconic British organisation and be part of a team focused on excellence and innovation to drive real-world solutions to complex challenges.”

On LinkedIn, she added: “I’m excited to start 2026 by joining Rolls-Royce as Global Head of Government Relations and Chief Sustainability Officer.” She described her bp experience as “highly formative and rewarding” and continued: “I am deeply thankful for the experiences, the trust, and most importantly the people I had the pleasure of working with. To the teams, colleagues and partners across bp, my best wishes in the year to come.”

RELATED ARTICLE: Rolls-Royce Rapidly Powers Sustainable Aviation with Ansys and Intel Technologies

Implications for Governance, Policy and Investors

The appointment lands at a time when industrial firms are facing simultaneous demands: accelerate decarbonisation, secure supply chains, manage cost of capital, and navigate proliferating disclosure and taxonomy regimes across the EU, UK and US.

Rolls Royce has been exploring next generation small modular nuclear reactors for both national energy security and export markets. It has also been working on sustainable aviation fuel pathways and propulsion efficiency for the civil aviation sector. All three arenas are reliant on public policy, regulatory certainty and government procurement.

For institutional investors with exposure to aerospace, defense and energy transition infrastructure, the combined government relations and sustainability role may streamline engagement on climate transition, industrial policy, and regulatory risk. It could also signal that high-emitting and strategically sensitive industrials expect climate and energy transition outcomes to be decided as much in parliaments and negotiating rooms as in capital markets.

What to Watch

C suite leaders and sustainable finance professionals will be looking for clarity on how Rolls Royce integrates climate strategy with policy advocacy. The company sits at the intersection of NATO country defense spending, net zero aviation debates, nuclear energy innovation, and industrial competitiveness. Each features distinct timelines, stakeholders and capital needs.

The global significance of the move lies in a broader trend: climate transition is becoming inseparable from geopolitics, industrial strategy and national security. Firms operating in those arenas are seeking leadership that can navigate governments, disclosure regimes, and investor expectations simultaneously.

title: Waste-Based Sustainable Aviation Fuel Could Power Your Next Flight | Happy Eco News
description:
Reading Time: 3 minutes Waste-based sustainable aviation fuel could generate 62.5 billion liters of jet fuel annually while reducing emissions by 80-90%.
Scientists have found a way to turn everyday trash into jet fuel that produces 80-90% less carbon than traditional aviation fuel.
Enter waste-based sustainable aviation fuel.
The waste-based sustainable aviation fuel meets current industry standards and can be used directly in airplanes without mixing it with conventional fuel.
As gasification and refining technologies improve, waste-based sustainable aviation fuel may become increasingly practical and affordable.
text:
Reading Time: 3 minutes

Waste-based sustainable aviation fuel could generate 62.5 billion liters of jet fuel annually while reducing emissions by 80-90%.

Scientists have found a way to turn everyday trash into jet fuel that produces 80-90% less carbon than traditional aviation fuel. The breakthrough could transform the 2-3% of global greenhouse gas emissions that come from air travel.

Research published recently in Science Direct shows that waste headed for landfills could produce 62.5 billion liters of jet fuel annually. This waste-based sustainable aviation fuel would cover a significant portion of aviation’s fuel needs while keeping organic waste out of dumps where it would decompose and release methane.

The aviation industry faces a major challenge in reducing its carbon footprint. Unlike cars or trucks, which can switch to electric power, airplanes require fuel that packs tremendous energy into a small, lightweight package. This makes the industry one of the hardest to clean up from a climate perspective.

Current alternative fuel options, called sustainable aviation fuels, face their own problems. Growing crops specifically for fuel can displace natural habitats or divert land from food production. This creates new environmental problems while trying to solve old ones.

Enter waste-based sustainable aviation fuel. Michael McElroy, an environmental studies professor at Harvard University, notes that organic waste offers an overlooked opportunity. Cities already collect garbage regularly, and the supply stays consistent throughout the year. These factors make municipal solid waste an attractive starting material for fuel production.

Until now, no one had crunched the numbers on trash-based jet fuel at a global scale, using real data from actual production facilities. An international research team from the United States and China calculated that incorporating waste-based fuel into aviation could reduce the industry’s greenhouse gas emissions by 16%. This would mean the emissions from roughly one out of six flights would be eliminated.

The process isn’t simple. Garbage contains everything from food scraps to paper to yard waste, creating a literal mixed bag of materials. This variety requires more processing steps and more energy to convert trash into usable fuel compared to using a single crop type.

The biggest hurdle happens right at the start. Ming Zhao, an environmental engineering professor at Tsinghua University in Beijing, explains that gasification technology remains a core challenge. This process converts solid waste into a mixture of gases that can then be refined into fuel. Getting it to work reliably and efficiently determines whether the whole system succeeds.

Scientists continue making progress on these technical challenges. A separate team at the University of Illinois focuses specifically on food waste, which makes up the largest portion of what most households discard. They developed a faster method using a process called hydrothermal liquefaction, which converts food scraps into a thick, energy-rich liquid.

The catch with this biocrude oil is its inconsistent chemical makeup. Jet engines require fuel with very specific, uniform properties for safety and performance reasons. The Illinois researchers tested dozens of chemical catalysts to refine the biocrude and found a cobalt-molybdenum combination that works in a single step.

The waste-based sustainable aviation fuel meets current industry standards and can be used directly in airplanes without mixing it with conventional fuel. This marks the first time researchers have achieved this milestone with food waste as the starting material. The same biocrude can also be refined into gasoline and diesel for cars and trucks.

Despite these advances, both research teams acknowledge an important limitation of the waste-based sustainable aviation fuel. Neither food waste nor municipal solid waste alone could completely replace conventional jet fuel. This reality highlights the substantial amount of fuel consumed by the aviation industry and the numerous solutions needed to fully decarbonize air travel.

The waste-based sustainable aviation fuel approach offers several advantages beyond emissions reduction. It addresses two problems at once by diverting organic material from landfills while creating a valuable product. Cities spend a significant amount of money managing waste, so converting garbage into fuel could help offset some of these costs.

The technology also avoids competing with food production and does not require new land to grow fuel crops. The collection infrastructure already exists in most cities worldwide. These factors could make trash-based fuel easier to scale up compared to other alternative fuel options.

See also: France and Spain Lead Europe’s Push for a Luxury Aviation Tax

However, building the processing facilities and refining operations requires substantial investment. The technology needs to prove itself at a commercial scale, not just in research laboratories. Fuel made from waste must also compete on price with conventional jet fuel, which remains relatively cheap.

Airlines have committed to achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, but they need viable alternatives to make this goal a reality. Sustainable aviation fuels derived from various sources, including waste, are likely to play a crucial role in meeting these targets. Regulatory support and financial incentives may help accelerate the adoption of these cleaner fuel options.

The research demonstrates that waste materials previously considered worthless can become valuable energy resources. As gasification and refining technologies improve, waste-based sustainable aviation fuel may become increasingly practical and affordable. This could help make air travel more compatible with climate goals while improving waste management.

title: IATA Reports Slowing Growth of Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production - Blog
description:
Slowing Momentum in Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production The aviation sector’s shift towards sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) continues to be a hot topic with ambitious goals for decarbonization.
Policy choices, especially in Europe, appear to be key culprits in holding back the scale-up of SAF production capacity.
Efforts by sustainable aviation fuel advocates stress that progress depends not only on ramping up production but ensuring the fuel remains economically viable and scalable without disrupting other sectors such as agriculture.
Implications for Air Cargo and Global Logistics The repercussions of SAF production trends stretch beyond just the commercial passenger airlines; freight and cargo logistics are closely tied to the aviation fuel market.
When SAF production growth slows, the sector risks missing critical environmental targets, keeping carbon emissions from air freight and courier services higher for longer.
text:
Slowing Momentum in Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production

The aviation sector’s shift towards sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) continues to be a hot topic with ambitious goals for decarbonization. However, a closer look reveals that although production of SAF is projected to nearly double this year—from 1 million tonnes in 2024 up to 1.9 million tonnes in 2025—the growth rate is already showing signs of tapering off. This slowing momentum poses challenges in meeting the airline industry’s ambitious carbon reduction targets and raises questions about the pace at which sustainable fuels can replace conventional jet fuels.

Why Has Growth Slowed?

Policy choices, especially in Europe, appear to be key culprits in holding back the scale-up of SAF production capacity. Despite the potential for SAF to significantly cut carbon emissions compared to traditional fossil fuels, regulatory frameworks have sometimes been misaligned or too slow to adapt. This has resulted in slower investments and hesitant production expansion.

Efforts by sustainable aviation fuel advocates stress that progress depends not only on ramping up production but ensuring the fuel remains economically viable and scalable without disrupting other sectors such as agriculture. The preferred feedstocks for SAF often include waste products like used cooking oil, algae, and non-food crops, which don’t compete with food supply chains.

Implications for Air Cargo and Global Logistics

The repercussions of SAF production trends stretch beyond just the commercial passenger airlines; freight and cargo logistics are closely tied to the aviation fuel market. Sustainable fuels could reshape the cost structures and environmental impact of air freight, which remains a vital artery for global supply chains—especially for time-sensitive and high-value items.

When SAF production growth slows, the sector risks missing critical environmental targets, keeping carbon emissions from air freight and courier services higher for longer. This creates a ripple effect throughout industries reliant on quick and reliable global distribution, from electronics to pharmaceuticals.

Table: Projected Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production Growth

Year Estimated SAF Production (million tonnes) Growth Rate Decarbonization Goal Alignment 2024 1.0 Baseline Initial scaling 2025 1.9 ~90% increase Growth slowing, falling short Beyond 2025 Limited projections Uncertain, below targets Potential gap in meeting targets

Challenges Facing the Aviation Fuel Transition

There are no shortcuts here—transforming the aviation fuel industry is like turning a massive ship; it can’t happen overnight. SAF production involves complex supply chains and requires substantial capital investments in new facilities and technology. The current mismatch between policy ambitions and practical on-the-ground realities slows infrastructure growth and investor confidence.

Moreover, it’s critical to ensure that SAF production does not inadvertently create new environmental or social issues, such as land use conflicts or biodiversity loss, which some traditional biofuel sources have been criticized for. The aviation industry, including groups like the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Users Group (SAFUG), advocates for fuels that minimize negative side effects and integrate seamlessly with existing aircraft engines and fuel distribution networks.

Impacts on Logistics Providers and Freight Forwarders

For logistics operators, air freight remains an essential part of global distribution, especially when speed is of the essence. The current plateauing of SAF production means that reliance on traditional jet fuel will persist longer than anticipated, forcing freight companies to keep factoring in rising costs and environmental concerns. This could pressure logistics strategies to diversify transportation modes and seek greener alternatives where feasible.

Heading Toward Sustainable Transport Solutions

While SAF is a promising piece of the broader green transport puzzle, it highlights a key lesson: sustainability transitions in logistics and transportation require coordinated policy, technology, and market support. Companies engaged in cargo delivery, moving, and freight forwarding must stay informed about these fuel shifts as they can influence pricing, availability, and compliance demands globally.

Key Takeaways:

SAF growth is strong but losing steam, which may affect meeting climate goals in aviation.

Policy misalignment in major regions like Europe contributes to slower production scale-up.

Air freight logistics could face persistent challenges, as SAF supply lags demand growth.

Focus on sustainable feedstocks helps balance environmental and economic objectives.

Logistics operators need to stay agile, incorporating sustainable fuels and planning for evolving supply chains.

It’s worth remembering that while industry reviews and analyses provide valuable insights, there’s no substitute for firsthand experience. Getting involved in actual cargo transportation through platforms like GetTransport.com offers a practical way to navigate these evolving logistics landscapes. This platform excels by offering affordable, international transport solutions including house moves, bulky freight, vehicle transport, and office relocations, making sustainable logistics accessible and straightforward.

By tapping into GetTransport.com, businesses and individuals gain transparency and choice, ensuring they harness the best service at competitive rates without the hassle. Whether it’s moving heavy cargo or planning an international shipment, the platform’s versatility makes logistics less of a bear and more of a breeze. Book your ride at GetTransport.com.com to experience this first hand.

Looking ahead, the implications of slowing SAF expansion might not radically disrupt global logistics on their own, but they underscore the importance of staying attuned to the transport sector’s evolution. At GetTransport.com, keeping pace with such changes is part of the mission to provide dependable, cost-effective freight and shipment solutions worldwide. Start planning your next delivery and secure your cargo with GetTransport.com.

Summary

The anticipated growth of sustainable aviation fuel holds significant promise for reducing carbon emissions in air transport, but current trends show a deceleration that could delay the aviation sector’s environmental progress. For the logistics and freight industries, this means continued reliance on conventional fuels in the near term, pushing the need for innovations in sustainable transport and more strategic planning. Platforms like GetTransport.com offer practical, affordable ways to manage these challenges across global supply chains by embracing flexibility, diverse transport options, and cost efficiency. Ultimately, addressing fuel sustainability is a shared responsibility, and logistics providers must be ready to adapt as the industry charts its green future.

title: NEG8 & Prochem Partner On An Engineering Study For A New DAC Project In Ireland
description:
Direct air capture (DAC) specialist NEG8 Carbon and engineering consultancy firm Prochem Engineering have signed a landmark agreement for an engineering study that will define the project specifications of Ireland’s first full-scale carbon capture system.
The system, set to be constructed at the NEG8 Carbon Waterford headquarters, is projected to be able to attract and capture 50 tonnes of CO2 annually.
For NEG8, this system will also be the first developed module with the company’s direct air capture technology.
Through the joint engineering study with Prochem, NEG8 hopes to be able to unlock refinements for its DAC technology that will allow price reductions and pave the way for the global commercial deployment of these systems.
To kick off the partnership, NEG8 welcomed a team of Prochem representatives to the selected project site, where attendees got a chance to tour the location.
text:
Direct air capture (DAC) specialist NEG8 Carbon and engineering consultancy firm Prochem Engineering have signed a landmark agreement for an engineering study that will define the project specifications of Ireland’s first full-scale carbon capture system.

The system, set to be constructed at the NEG8 Carbon Waterford headquarters, is projected to be able to attract and capture 50 tonnes of CO2 annually. For NEG8, this system will also be the first developed module with the company’s direct air capture technology.

Established in 2014 as a spin-out from CO2 capture research at Trinity College Dublin and University College Dublin, NEG8 specializes in novel electrostatic DAC technology that captures atmospheric carbon emissions.

Its system works by pulling in air and passing it through a custom-designed sorbent system that attracts and captures CO2 molecules. Once captured, the carbon can then be permanently stored underground or used in the production of materials like sustainable aviation fuel.

Through the joint engineering study with Prochem, NEG8 hopes to be able to unlock refinements for its DAC technology that will allow price reductions and pave the way for the global commercial deployment of these systems.

«Synthetic fuel can make DAC viable,» Harvey Hodd, Rivan Industries CEO

As part of the collaboration, Prochem will provide its expertise gained through more than 30 years of experience that have established it as one of the leading engineering consultancy firms in Ireland.

To kick off the partnership, NEG8 welcomed a team of Prochem representatives to the selected project site, where attendees got a chance to tour the location.

Commenting on this exciting announcement, NEG8 Chief Technology Officer Dr. John Breen stated, “The 50 tonne/annum unit will serve to validate NEG8’s system as a leading engineered carbon capture technology that will support industries and governments in their drive to net-zero and beyond to negative carbon emissions.”

Relevant: Ireland’s NEG8 Carbon Advances DAC Technology With Breakthrough Innovations

Michael Kent, Director at Kilkenny-headquartered Prochem Engineering, commented,

“We are excited to be working alongside NEG8 Carbon on this groundbreaking project, which highlights the exceptional level of engineering capability, innovation, and technical excellence available in Ireland.”

He added, “This collaboration reflects the shared commitment of NEG8 Carbon and Prochem Engineering to deliver innovative, sustainable engineering solutions that support meaningful environmental progress and a lower-carbon future.”

title: Explaining F1's new 2026 regulations: What's new and what it means - McLaren
description:
The cars evolve constantly – but for 2026, revolution rather than evolution is the order of things with wholesale changes to both chassis and engine regulations.
We’ll get into all of that over the next few months, but for the moment, here are the top notes for the all-new 2026 F1 Championship.
After 11 seasons with, in essence, the same power unit architecture, F1 has had a rethink for 2026.
Moving to 100 per cent advanced, sustainable, carbon-neutral fuels is part of F1’s roadmap to a net-zero carbon footprint.
The fuels used in F1 are complex creations tailored to their engines: designing any new fuel for the 2026 regs was going to be challenging - doing it with a sustainable fuel, doubly so.
text:
Read time: 10.4 minutes

Formula 1 thrives on change. The cars evolve constantly – but for 2026, revolution rather than evolution is the order of things with wholesale changes to both chassis and engine regulations.

After 11 seasons, the original hybrid F1 power unit spec has been retired, while after a brief, four-season foray into ground-effect, the sport will also undergo an aerodynamic reboot. There’s a lot to unpack: fresh philosophies, new jargon, and a lot of numbers. We’ll get into all of that over the next few months, but for the moment, here are the top notes for the all-new 2026 F1 Championship.

Let’s talk horsepower. What’s changing with the power units?

After 11 seasons with, in essence, the same power unit architecture, F1 has had a rethink for 2026. The 1.6L V6 turbocharged internal combustion engine (ICE) remains, but the MGU-H (which used the flow of exhaust gas to spin a turbine and reclaim energy) has been removed. The MGU-K (which reclaims energy while braking) will be beefed up to harvest and deploy about three times as much energy as its predecessor, with the goal of the new power unit having a roughly 50:50 split between power supplied by the ICE and from the electric system.

With the MGU-H – viewed as complicated and less road-relevant – removed, the new ’26 power units are being hailed as a simplified hybrid system. The reality is a little more complex: this is – as always with F1 – cutting-edge technology, attempting to do something that’s never been done before.

We’re also having an aerodynamic reboot. Isn’t it unusual to do both at the same time?

It isn’t the way F1 usually operates – but this aerodynamic reboot is designed to complement the new power unit… while also addressing a few of F1’s long-standing issues. The new power units are expected to produce a little less power than their predecessors, but to keep lap times in a similar range, the cars have reduced drag and a lower minimum weight, aided by narrower floor and tyres, and a shorter wheelbase.

What are the most prominent aero changes?

The front wing is of a much simpler design with fewer elements, though the endplates have a little more scope for exotic solutions. The ‘eyebrow’ winglets over the front wheels have also been deleted, with new bargeboards appearing. Less noticeable but fundamental to the design is the removal of the Venturi tunnels under the car. Ground-effect goes back into the box as flat(ter) floors return, with a larger diffuser, and the beam (i.e. lower) wing deleted.

Is the new aero package going to impact racing?

Certainly, it is intended to. As has been the case with the previous two aerodynamic iterations, the regulations have been written with the intention of improving racing and increasing overtaking, by enabling cars to be able to follow each other more closely.

The car’s front wheels punch a big hole in the airflow. Designers like to push that turbulent air out to the side of the car (out-washing), allowing smoother air to infill and make the aerodynamic surfaces more effective… but out-washing creates a bigger turbulent wake that makes it much more difficult for the car behind to close in. 2022’s regs were designed to combat the creation of this wake and were initially very successful before teams began clawing back their outwash-generating aerodynamics. These regs have taken that learning and will make it much harder to generate an outwash. Not that teams won’t try…

Beyond controlling the wake, the new regs are also creating a stronger, safer car and, it is hoped, one that is a little more nimble. Roll hoops have a new test to pass that raises the load from 16g to 20g, while the nose now has a two-stage impact structure. The latter is to deal with the issue of secondary impacts – i.e. those times when the front of the car has a heavy impact, spins and then has another heavy impact.

In terms of making a car that is more nimble, the 2026 regs specify a wheelbase that is 200mm shorter, a floor 100mm narrower and a minimum weight reduced from 798kg to 768kg. Whether or not anyone can get close to that minimum remains to be seen.

These cars have active aero. What’s that?

DRS no longer exists… but the cars now feature an adjustable rear wing that will open like DRS on all straights to reduce drag, irrespective of the race situation. The front wing will also move, working together with the rear wing to better trim the car. They’ll close again before corners to maximise downforce – in much the same way DRS did.

What are these modes we are hearing about?

There’s quite a bit of jargon floating about this year. The active aero modes were originally labelled X mode and Z mode. These will now be called Straight Mode and Corner Mode… you can probably extrapolate from context when those are to be used.

If a car is within one second of the car ahead when it passes a detection point (usually the final corner) Overtake Mode will be activated on the following lap. This will provide a speed boost, but also a lap in which it can recover more energy. This looks like it will be the primary overtaking device in the new formula. In ‘normal’ mode, the electrical energy that can be deployed begins to taper off at 290km/h. With Overtake Mode activated, the maximum 350kW will be available up to 337km/h, then tapering off up to 350km/h.

Other words you may hear flying around are Boost and Recharge. A boost button allows the driver to manually deploy electrical energy, in much the same way they’d done in the current generation of cars, while Recharge is the energy recovery function. It’s similar to what’s gone on before, but with a few more options than during the 2014-2025 era.

Will sustainable fuels make a difference?

Moving to 100 per cent advanced, sustainable, carbon-neutral fuels is part of F1’s roadmap to a net-zero carbon footprint. F1 had been running with a 10 per cent bioethanol fuel, but now converts fully to either an e-fuel or something created from waste biomass. The fuels used in F1 are complex creations tailored to their engines: designing any new fuel for the 2026 regs was going to be challenging - doing it with a sustainable fuel, doubly so. The expectation is that the new blends will be slightly less calorific than their fossil predecessors… but development will be rapid over the next few years. Expect this to be a more competitive arena than it has been recently.

title: Will Ukrainian energy become a magnet for EU green investments? - ceenergynews
description:
In the European energy sector, 2022–2025 became a period of rethinking.
Just yesterday, the world was trying to find a balance between cheap gas, the growth of green energy, and the logic of the electricity market.
The World and the EU in 2022-2025: New Rules, New Networks, New Consumers The European Union responded to the energy shock with packages of new rules and investments.
Investors should make decisions about this, and the regulatory background is already clear, thanks to European rules and Ukrainian policies in the field of hydrogen energy.
We need our own accelerated grid reconstruction plan with a priority for the rapid connection of new generation and storage facilities, like the Energy Infrastructure Plan for Europe.
text:
Op-ed by Oleksiy Hnatenko, Partner at Juscutum.

In the European energy sector, 2022–2025 became a period of rethinking. Just yesterday, the world was trying to find a balance between cheap gas, the growth of green energy, and the logic of the electricity market. But today, Europe is already building new networks, introducing digital rules for trade transparency, and preparing space for industries that are sharply increasing demand for electricity, starting with data centres and ending with electric transport.

During this same time, Ukraine has lived several “energy lives”. It lost energy infrastructure facilities after missile strikes and simultaneously synchronised with the European network, put into operation the largest energy storage systems in the region, and reshaped the investment optics of business. It is painful, but productive: the war forced us to move from the “theory of transition” to the “practice of sustainability”.

The World and the EU in 2022-2025: New Rules, New Networks, New Consumers

The European Union responded to the energy shock with packages of new rules and investments. The electricity market reform consolidated stable long-term instruments and reduced the impact of gas price fluctuations on the price of electricity. In parallel, the modernisation of energy trade supervision increased transparency and responsibility of players. At the infrastructure level, a plan for the rapid completion of networks and interstate connections appeared. And, finally, a new major consumer entered the European agenda – artificial intelligence with its data centres, which in a few years will add dozens of terawatt-hours of demand and force the acceleration of investments in networks, flexibility and demand management.

A separate trend for 2022-2025 is the return of hydrogen from the plane of slogans to the plane of rules and investments. The EU has launched the European Hydrogen Bank with production support auctions, defined green criteria for electrolyser hydrogen (RFNBO) and low-carbon hydrogen, and enabled the phased development of hydrogen infrastructure within the framework of projects of common interest. This loop is connected to transport: at sea, requirements to reduce the carbon intensity of fuel on ships have come into force, in aviation, minimum shares of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), opening the door to e-methanol and “green” ammonia as energy carriers in these areas.

Europe’s hydrogen ambitions are no longer an abstraction. In 2025, the world’s first commercial e-methanol plant, powered by renewable electricity and captured CO₂, opened in Denmark. The maritime industry has also accelerated contracts for the new fuel. This does not yet solve all the cost problems, but it is already shaping a market with forecasted demand.

Ukraine in 2025: Networks, Imports and Internal Flexibility

After emergency synchronisation with the European network in March 2022, Ukraine not only kept its power system operational, but also opened commercial trade. For the autumn-winter period of 2024-2025, European operators increased the limit on electricity imports to Ukraine to 2.1 gigawatts (GW). This volume was agreed not within the framework of a preferential regime, but determined by the technical capabilities of the system, which has been tested by war and, in this regime, fulfils the conditions of a stabilisation nature.

Ukraine’s response to the electricity shortage and the destruction and decommissioning of energy infrastructure due to Russian shelling was the need to create internal flexibility. In 2025, private investors introduced a portfolio of energy storage systems with a total capacity of 200 megawatts and a capacity of 400 MWh. These are six sites optimised for balancing and emergency modes, which are already undergoing commercial testing and will operate under contracts with the transmission system operator. To put it simply, two hours of reserve for hundreds of thousands of households, exactly when it is needed most.

This did not arise in a vacuum. Back in 2023–2024, the business was massively diversifying towards gas-piston plants and small-scale cogeneration. Cities were buying mini-CHPs based on Jenbacher engines, international partners were importing modular gas turbines, and state-owned companies were launching peak decentralised production programs. All this is a forced pragmatic reaction to blackouts and shortages of energy resources.

In parallel, the regulator adjusted the rules to the new reality. Separate procedures for ancillary services auctions appeared, where storage systems and fast generation can compete for long-term contracts. For wartime, this is a conservative, but timely and reliable innovation, according to which the market receives a clear signal, the operator receives a resource for system control, and the consumer can count on a stable energy supply and a decrease in the number of outages.

Hydrogen, ammonia and methanol: European logic – Ukrainian opportunities

The EU has laid the basic conditions for a large hydrogen market. Support for production through auctions, unified methods for confirming the origin of “green” hydrogen and recognition of low-carbon hydrogen are the market rules that were missing yesterday. Further, regulation covers transport: shipping receives an obligation to reduce carbon fuel intensity, aviation – minimal shares of sustainable fuels. At this stage, hydrogen derivatives – e-methanol and “green” ammonia – come into play.

E-methanol is synthesised from hydrogen and carbon dioxide using renewable electricity, while ammonia is produced from hydrogen and nitrogen from the air. These are liquid energy carriers that are easier to store and transport using the existing bulk infrastructure, so in the transitional years, they become a practical bridge between hydrogen producers and consumers, starting from the chemical industry and the agricultural sector and ending with shipping and aviation.

Ukraine can integrate into this chain from two sides. The first is infrastructure: we have port and chemical assets on the Black Sea, including the Odessa Port Plant, which traditionally worked with ammonia. Its privatisation track in 2025 creates a platform for a restart for “green” products after the war, and not only for classic fertilisers. The second is hydrogen derivative production projects in the logic of future export flows. Investors should make decisions about this, and the regulatory background is already clear, thanks to European rules and Ukrainian policies in the field of hydrogen energy.

For general clarity, it should be noted that we are not ahead of events. Even in Europe, e-methanol projects are only moving from pilots to industrial scales this year. But right now, a “demand funnel” is forming – from ports and logistics to shipping and aviation. Entering it with the right timing means getting a solvent buyer and financing for the export logistics.

Investment instruments in war: what works in practice

Classical investment instruments continue to operate, but with a risk adjustment. Project financing with guarantees from international financial institutions, political risk insurance, blending grants and loans, long-term power purchase agreements and system services are what drive new projects even under fire. When it comes to critical infrastructure, banks and donors are becoming co-investors in resilience, not just lenders. For example, package financing for peak generation and storage systems, which international development banks approved in 2025, was precisely a response to the lack of flexibility and winter risks.

An important nuance remains the networks. The development of data centres and electrification in Europe has already raised the bar for connection requirements and demand management. Demand is growing, and the window for connections is narrowing. For Ukraine, this is also a signal that every new megawatt of wind or solar must immediately receive a place in the network and a contract for flexibility. Otherwise, investors will not pay for generation, but for downtime.

Corruption scandals: not verdicts, but risk premiums

Recent months have given the market several high-profile stories with the arrests of top officials in the energy sector. Together with our lawyer colleagues, we do not give legal assessments and do not substitute for the court. We look at this as a risk factor. For international partners, this adds a premium to the cost of capital, complicates the structure of deals and increases the role of prior conditions: audits, compliance, and transparency of procurement. If a country shows that investigations are going to the top and are being completed procedurally correctly, investors take this into account and return to the project figures. If the turbulence is systemic, the share of grant components increases, and debt resources become more expensive. This is the logic of investment and the mathematics of risk in wartime.

Lessons from the Balkans: What the experience of Croatia and its neighbours says

After the wars of the 1990s, the countries of the former Yugoslavia went through a very similar cycle. First, stabilisation and large-scale intergovernmental initiatives like the Stability Pact, which, under pressure from the EU and international banks, opened up financing specifically for infrastructure. Then came privatisation and the long, sometimes painful modernisation of utility and energy assets, which attracted private capital only after the emergence of clear rules and regulatory safeguards. Croatia came to this through institutional reforms and European integration requirements, and investments in networks and generation were a consequence, not a cause. This is not idealisation, but a useful road map for us, focused on a different paradigm, based on the principle of “first rules and networks, then large-scale investments”.

Forecast for 2026: more networks, more flexibility, more hydrogen

A realistic scenario for Ukraine for 2026 consists of three mandatory elements.

The first is networks and connections. Europe is doubling down on interconnectors and internal lines because, without them, it will not be able to sustain either renewables or data centres. We need our own accelerated grid reconstruction plan with a priority for the rapid connection of new generation and storage facilities, like the Energy Infrastructure Plan for Europe. In the long term, this is cheaper than chronic outages.

The second is flexibility as a business. Portfolio storage systems, fast peaking stations, demand management and new ancillary services markets are not a temporary solution for wartime, but a new reality. Transmission system operator contracts, a clear auction schedule and seamless integration with European regulations, that’s where the difference between projects on paper and commissioned capacities lies.

Third – hydrogen derivatives, ammonia, e-methanol, as an export strategy. We should not compete for the “greenest hydrogen in the world” tomorrow. It is worth laying the foundation for the export of products that are easier to export and for which buyers are already appearing, namely e-methanol and “green” ammonia. This requires solutions that ensure transparent privatisation and reprofiling of port and chemical assets, transparent access to networks, and contractual bridges with European consumers. The rules in the EU already exist, and our strategies are currently under open discussion. Time is pressing, but it does not punish those who act systematically and consistently.

What this means for business and politics

For investors, the signal is simple. Ukrainian energy after 2025 is about networks and flexibility in connection with long-term contracts, plus niche industries based on hydrogen derivatives, where the region can become the production arm of the EU. The cost of capital will depend on the quality of risk management, not just on the scale of assets. The key for politicians will be to quickly create a regulatory framework between national and European legislation, protect competition in auctions and make export logistics predictable.

For citizens, the most important thing is the availability of energy resources and the ease of commissioning energy-efficient solutions. Everything else is just a way to achieve this. Ukraine enters 2026 with the experience of survival and a set of working solutions. Europe is shaping the demand for green electricity, diversifying its sources of natural gas and oil, and developing new markets for hydrogen and its derivatives. At the intersection of these two trajectories lies what we call an opportunity, which Ukraine has a chance to seize.

title: Bioethanol to jet fuel | Biofuels International Magazine
description:
The larger ethanol molecule yields the heavier kerosene fraction that is required for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
At a global level, the price of these nutritional commodities is being driven up by their competing use as a fuel.
Syngas derived from biomass gasification is CO-rich and is an ideal feedstock for the LanzaTech process.
As an alternative to power generation or flaring, utilisation of the BFG and BOFG in the LanzaTech process can generate ethanol.
Dehydration of ethanol on the way to produce kerosene Ethanol is an alcohol based on two carbon atoms.
text:
The conversion of methanol and ethanol to hydrocarbon fuels has been done for many years. The two dominant pathways are methanol to gasoline (MTG) and ethanol to jet (ETJ), which is also known as ethanol to kerosene (ETK), writes Stephen B. Harrison, Managing Director at sbh4 consulting, Germany.

.The smaller methanol molecule is ideal to produce the lighter gasoline fraction for cars. The larger ethanol molecule yields the heavier kerosene fraction that is required for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

Plant-based bio-ethanol

Traditionally, bioethanol has been produced from fermentation of sugary broths at industrial scale. The process is essentially the same as making beer from grain and then distilling the beer to make whisky.

In Asia and the Americas, the most widely used crops for bio-ethanol production are maize and sugar cane. Rice, sorghum and cassava are also used in secondary quantities. In Europe, these crops are generally replaced by wheat and sugar-beet.

Considering these crops, it is evident that agricultural land and food crops are being diverted to the production of biofuels as affordable energy vectors. At a global level, the price of these nutritional commodities is being driven up by their competing use as a fuel. For the rich, a few cents more for a kilo of wheat or rice will not drive a family into starvation. For impoverished nations, the same is not true.

The need for alternative non-food sources of sustainable ethanol is a global imperative. And, if it can also be produced from industrial emissions, this will surely be a win-win scenario.

Industrial ethanol from recycled carbon

The US company LanzaTech utilises anaerobic acetobacter bacteria in a fermenter to convert carbon monoxide (CO) rich feed gases, such as syngas, to ethanol and a range of biochemicals. The term CCT or ‘Carbon Capture and Transformation’ has been used to describe the LanzaTech fermentation process.

The ideal feedstocks for the LanzaTech fermenter are CO-rich. Syngas derived from biomass gasification is CO-rich and is an ideal feedstock for the LanzaTech process.

Iron and steel making also yields CO-rich flue gases. Blast furnace gas (BFG) contains 20% CO and converter gas (also known as basic oxygen furnace gas or BOFG) contains 60% CO.

At present, the energy rich BOFG (LHV 3 kWh/Nm3) is often utilised on the iron and steel making facility for heat or power generation on a gas engine. Alternatively, it is flared. BFG has a lower energy value because it contains less CO (LHV 0.9 kWh/Nm3). It can also be utilised for heat and power generation, or is sent to the flare.

As an alternative to power generation or flaring, utilisation of the BFG and BOFG in the LanzaTech process can generate ethanol. Subsequently, the complimentary LanzaJet process can be used to convert the ethanol to SAF in their proprietary ETJ process.

Lifecycle analysis

The LanzaTech bioreactor utilises CO from syngas to grow bacterial biomass in the fermenter. Some gases are emitted from the fermenter. This biomass from the fermenter is subsequently converted to biomethane in a separate anaerobic sludge digester. This energy-rich biomethane which is used to fully combust the main fermenter off gases to CO2. This CO2 can either then be emitted to the air or captured.

Life cycle analysis (LCA) of the LanzaTech process shows that CO2 emissions reduction is primarily due to the substitution of fossil fuels or crude-oil derived plastics with biomaterials produced from ethanol or other co-products recovered from the fermentation broth.

Also integral to the LanzaTech LCA is consideration of whether the feedstock, such as iron and steel making flue gases are flared, or utilised. If they are flared, their recovery and conversion to ethanol is a significant environmental benefit. However, if they are utilised to make heat and power, they already avoid the use of fossil fuels and the overall CO2 reduction in the LCA is reduced.

Scaling up successfully

LanzaTech’s process was demonstrated at pilot-scale in 2008 using flue gases from the BlueScope Steel mill in Glenbrook, NZ. Since then, LanzaTech has successfully deployed its technology at two 300 tonne per annum demonstration facilities at Baosteel Shanghai and Shougang Steel Caofeidian in China. These LanzaTech fermenters are fed with a range of iron and steel making off gases including BOFG, BFG, and coke oven gas (COG).

LanzaTech also operates the Freedom Pines Biorefinery in Soperton, Georgia which uses bio fermenters to generate ethanol and other chemicals. The LanzaJet ETJ SAF production process has also been implemented at that location.

Dehydration of ethanol on the way to produce kerosene

Ethanol is an alcohol based on two carbon atoms. As an alcohol, it contains an oxygen atom. Kerosene, on the other hand, is a long paraffinic hydrocarbon with between 10 and 14 carbon atoms that contains no oxygen.

Conversion of ethanol to kerosene takes place in two separate stages. The first is dehydration of ethanol to ethylene, or ethene. This effectively removes the oxygen atom and builds a highly reactive double bond linkage between the two carbon atoms.

The dehydration reaction is effected using a zeolite type catalyst such as H-ZSM-5 at between 250 and 300 °C. Low pressure operation is preferred to enable the production of gaseous ethylene. The reaction requires a very high heat input. This is a parasitic load on the process that consumes some of the energy of the feedstock to enable the conversion to kerosene.

Ethylene oligomerisation

The ethylene produced by the dehydration of ethanol is like a mouse trap, waiting to spring open. As the double bond between the two carbon atoms bond snaps open, it reaches out for another ethylene molecule to build butene a longer hydrocarbon containing four carbon atoms.

The conversion of ethylene to butene takes place over a nickel-based catalyst and releases a significant amount of heat, which can support the dehydration reaction.

Butene also contains a highly reactive carbon double bond. When several butene molecules are combined, very long hydrocarbons are created in a polymerisation reaction. If this reaction were left to proceed, the product would be polyethylene, a plastic polymer. To produce kerosene, the reaction must be initiated and then curtailed. This partial polymerisation is known as oligomerisation.

The oligomerisation proceeds using another zeolite catalyst such as ZSM-5. If it is conducted at high temperature, branched isomers of kerosene can be produced. These are desirable because they allow the fuel to be used at low temperatures (such as those at altitude) without freezing.

Hydrotreating and fractionation

The synthetic crude (syncrude) produced by oligomerisation may still contain some residual oxygen atoms from the ethanol feedstock. These must be removed to prevent corrosion of materials handling and storing the kerosene, and to prevent polymerisation of the fuel.

Hydrogen is reacted with the syncrude to remove oxygen and convert it into water. The deoxygenated syncrude is then distilled into fractions such as gasoline, diesel and kerosene for SAF.

The economics can be optimised by tailoring the process conditions to produce the most valuable fuel, which is SAF.

title: Demand for rapeseed imports declined due to an improved supply situation in the EU
description:
According to European Commission estimates, the rapeseed harvest in the EU-27 totalled around 20.16 million tonnes in 2025.
This translates to a significant increase in supply compared to the previous year's substandard 16.77 million tonnes.
With the rapeseed processing volume expected to reach around 24.68 million tonnes, it also makes the EU less dependent on imports.
By contrast, Moldova and Serbia ramped up their deliveries significantly compared to the first half of the crop year 2024/25, supplying 247,357 tonnes (previous year: 85,611 tonnes) and 114,171 tonnes (previous year: 44,501 tonnes), respectively.
Some of the rapeseed imports declared as Moldovan are likely to be of Ukrainian origin, reflecting changes in transit and trade routes.
text:
According to European Commission estimates, the rapeseed harvest in the EU-27 totalled around 20.16 million tonnes in 2025.

This translates to a significant increase in supply compared to the previous year's substandard 16.77 million tonnes.

With the rapeseed processing volume expected to reach around 24.68 million tonnes, it also makes the EU less dependent on imports.

Cumulative imports into the EU-27 in the first half of the crop year 2025/26 amounted to approximately 1.85 million tonnes, representing a nearly 43 per cent decline from the previous year's level of 3.23 million tonnes.

Ukraine remains the leading supplier country with just over 1.06 million tonnes to date and a 57 per cent share of imports. Nevertheless, the country's shipments remain clearly below the previous year's volume of 2.02 million tonnes.

The second wave of imports from Australia will increasingly come into focus later on in the season. By January, Australia had placed 249,869 tonnes of rapeseed on the EU market, ranking second among the major countries of origin with a share of just under 14 per cent, but trailing well behind Ukraine. According to investigations conducted by Agrarmarkt Informations-Gesellschaft (mbH), deliveries remained approximately 71 per cent below the level recorded in the reference period.

Canada continued to lose market share.

The country delivered 140,915 tonnes of rapeseed to date, which compares to 161,347 tonnes the previous year.

Because Canadian farmers grow genetically modified varieties, the use of rapeseed oil derived from Canadian rapeseed is restricted in the EU. As a result, imports from Canada are primarily used for biofuel production.

By contrast, Moldova and Serbia ramped up their deliveries significantly compared to the first half of the crop year 2024/25, supplying 247,357 tonnes (previous year: 85,611 tonnes) and 114,171 tonnes (previous year: 44,501 tonnes), respectively. Some of the rapeseed imports declared as Moldovan are likely to be of Ukrainian origin, reflecting changes in transit and trade routes.

text:
DICKINSON — On Wednesday at the Biesiot Activities Center, the North Dakota State University (NDSU) Dickinson Extension Center hosted its 29th annual “Diversity, Direction and Dollars” Ag Forum. The event was open to the public and included six presentations by researchers and market experts.

Doors opened at 8:30, and after a welcome from KDIX Radio’s Mike Renner, Chris Augustin, director of the Dickinson Research Extension Center, took the floor for his presentation, “Acid Soil Management in North Dakota No-till Soils.”

During his talk, Augustin gave a rundown on the basics of soil acidity and pH, mainly differentiating soil salinity or solidicity from soil acidity, which has to do with the concentration of hydrogen. Augustin explained that as soil pH decreases, that means that soil acidity increases. One of Augustin’s main points was that when soil pH measures as low as 5.5, that should register immediate concern. According to his research, incorporating lime into acidic soils helps to neutralize it.

Following Augustin was Chandler Mazour, who is a Nebraska native and product manager for GEVO and Verity Tracking. Mazour’s talk was titled “Carbon Intensity Counts: Monetizing Farm-Level Data.”

Mazour’s company acquired the Red Trail Energy facility in Richardton last year, and part of his presentation updated the crowd on that project, including the “carbon capture and sequestration efforts,” Mazour said. In the long term, it is GEVO’s goal to produce sustainable aviation fuel at their Richardton location. Mazour also said that his company is building out a grower program, working directly with farmers who want to track the carbon intensity of their own grain.

For the last presentation of the morning session, the forum welcomed Tommy Grisafi as its keynote speaker. Grisafi is a Risk Advisor and Commodity Broker for Advance Trading Inc., and is the owner of Ag Bull Media, which produces a popular agricultural podcast by the same name. Grisafi’s presentation was geared toward the risk management side of farming.

In addition to his own musings on stocks and market prices, Grisafi shared some observations he has made over the years of successful grain marketers and offered some practical advice for emulating their tactics, such as not second guessing one’s decisions, and not being afraid to invest in new technologies or equipment.

Following lunch, Frayne Olson, Crops Economist for NDSU, opened the afternoon session with his talk, “Buckle Up! 2026 Crop Market and Trade Outlook.” Olson shared several tables and graphs with the crowd, specifically focusing on the outlook for corn, soybean and wheat growers, comparing projections for the US market. He also covered US exports, with major buyers of US grains found in China, Mexico, Japan and Egypt.

The final two presentations were given by Joe Ikley, NDSU Extension Weed Specialist and Kevin Sedivec, who presented his talk entitled, “Is Virtual Fence the Future of Grazing Management: Pros and Cons.” Ikley went through the weed guide for this year during his presentation, “Herbicide Resistant Weeds and Best Practice Strategies for Control.”

What is Going on in the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Industry?

The rising awareness of environmental and climatic challenges, stringent environmental regulations, and growing push toward the circular economy initiative are reinforcing the shift towards sustainable formulation. Additionally, the global consumer preference for eco-friendly solutions is boosting demand for sustainable alternatives in paper manufacturing.

Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Report Highlights

The Asia Pacific dominated the global sustainable paper chemicals market with the largest volume share of 43.00% in 2025.

The sustainable paper chemicals market in North America is expected to grow at a substantial CAGR of 4.76% from 2026 to 2035.

By end use, the food and beverage packaging segment dominated the market and accounted for the largest volume share of 38.2% in 2025.

Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Report Scope

Major Government Initiatives for the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Industry:

Green Chemistry R&D Initiative: The Indian Government's Principal Scientific Adviser identifies the pulp and paper industry as a priority sector for developing a roadmap for sustainable R&D interventions.

Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme: This scheme offers financial benefits to boost domestic chemical manufacturing, incentivising the production of high-performance and eco-friendly specialty chemicals.

Ecomark Rules: Notified by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, these rules encourage demand for environmentally friendly paper products and sustainable production processes.

Chemical Promotion Development Scheme (CPDS): This initiative provides grants-in-aid to conduct workshops and research on green technologies and chemical safety within the industry.

Petrochemicals Research & Innovation Commendation (PRIC) Scheme: The government felicitates and rewards innovations in sustainable polymers and green manufacturing processes.

Centres of Excellence (CoE) for Sustainable Polymers: Specialized research centres provide funding to develop biodegradable polymers and bio-engineered materials as alternatives to traditional chemical additives.

Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) Guidelines: These guidelines mandate that producers of paper packaging take responsibility for collection and recycling, driving the adoption of recyclable chemical coatings and adhesives.

National BioE3 Policy: This policy fosters high-performance biomanufacturing to promote sustainable packaging materials, reducing dependency on fossil-fuel-based chemicals.

What Are the Major Trends inthe Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market?

Enzymatic & Microbial Processing: The major shift towards targeted enzymes and microbial feedstocks lowers energy and water consumption with improved fiber quality for high-performance applications.

Sustainability and Eco-Friendly Solutions: The increasing focus on reducing environmental impact and strict regulations is driving the adoption of green chemistry principles, bio-based and sustainable chemicals, and low-toxicity chemicals.

PFAS-Free Bio-based Coatings: Driven by manufacturers' implementation in biodegradable and compostable barrier coatings. Innovations in bio-based coatings provide grease and moisture resistance for food packaging without compromising recyclability.

Market Dynamics

Driver

The global push towards zero-waste manufacturing is driving the circular economy market, which enables repeated recycling cycles. With the rise in e-commerce, new specialized resins and retention have been developed to maintain the structural integrity of paper through multiple recycling cycles, supporting zero-waste production goals.

Restraint

The high production costs and raw material price volatility restrain the market. The manufacturing cost of eco-friendly, bio-based chemicals is higher than conventional chemicals. Additionally, the industry is challenged by a lack of reliable supply of raw material, restraining the market growth.

Market Opportunity

Which Bio-Materials Offer the Best Commercial Scalability?

The growing focus on industrial-scale production of seaweed extract, nanocellulose (MFC), and polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA) provides high grease resistance used in commercial-scale like home-compostable in food service and packaging solutions with improved performance for moisture resistance, durability, and printability.

Can Digital Innovation& Technological Shift Ensure Long-term Profitability and the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Leadership?

The industry is integrating AI-driven control systems, IoT sensors, and digital twins to provide real-time monitoring and automated, precise chemical dosing, which improves efficiency, minimizes waste, and ensures consistent product quality. The technological shift driving the development of press-applied aqueous dispersions and precision coating systems which accelerating the adoption of PFAS-free solutions.

As the global drive to replace single-use plastics with sustainable paper alternatives.
